column1: join_communist_bloc_desc;Join the Communist Bloc. Eastern Bloc was the name used by NATO-affiliated countries for the former communist states of Central and Eastern Europe
column2: generally the Soviet Union and the countries of the Warsaw Pact. The terms Communist Bloc and Soviet Bloc were also used to denote groupings of states aligned with the Soviet Union
column3: although these terms might include states outside Central and Eastern Europe.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: join_democratic_bloc_desc;Join the Democratic Bloc. The Western Bloc or Democratic Bloc during the Cold War refers to the countries allied with the United States and NATO against the Soviet Union and its allies. The latter were referred to as the Eastern Bloc
column2: a more common term in English than Western Bloc. The governments and press of the Western Bloc were more inclined to refer to themselves as the Free World or the Western world. ;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: join_nam_bloc_desc;The Non-Aligned Movement (NAM) is a group of states which are not formally aligned with or against any major power bloc. As of 2012
column2: the movement has 120 members. The organization was founded in Belgrade in 1961
column3: and was largely conceived by India's first prime minister
column4: Jawaharlal Nehru
column5: Indonesia's first president
column12: Josip Broz Tito. All five leaders were prominent advocates of a middle course for states in the Developing World between the Western and Eastern Blocs in the Cold War. The phrase itself was first used to represent the doctrine by Indian diplomat V. K. Krishna Menon in 1953

column2: also known as "Rome–Berlin–Tokyo Axis" were the nations that fought in World War II against the Allies. The Axis powers agreed on their opposition to the Allies
column3: but did not completely coordinate their activity.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: is an intergovernmental military alliance based on the North Atlantic Treaty which was signed 1949. The organization constitutes a system of collective defence whereby its member states agree to mutual defense in response to an attack by any external party.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: and all NATO troops were asked to leave our country.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: rio_pact_desc;The Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance (commonly known as the Rio Pact
column2: or by the Spanish-language acronym TIAR from Tratado Interamericano de Asistencia Recíproca) was an agreement signed on 1947 in Rio de Janeiro among many countries of the AmericasThe central principle contained in its articles is that an attack against one is to be considered an attack against them all; this was known as the "hemispheric defense" doctrine.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: leave_rio_pact_desc;Our countries have made the decision to bury what deserves to be buried
column2: or throw the trash bin that no longer serves. The Rio Treaty was created under conditions where it was assumed that could serve as an instrument of mutual protection of the countries of the Americas in the event of alleged attacks outside the continent;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: warsaw_pact_desc;The Warsaw Pact was a collective defence treaty among eight communist states of Central and Eastern Europe in existence during the Cold War. The Warsaw Pact was the military complement to the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CoMEcon)
column2: the regional economic organization for the communist States of Central and Eastern Europe. ;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: leave_warsaw_pact_desc;The Warsaw Pact was a collective defence treaty to defend the Communist regimes of Europe. We no longer desire to be members of such oppressive organisation.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: also known as the Berlin Pact
column3: was an agreement between Germany
column4: Italy and Japan signed in Berlin on 27 September 1940 by
column5: respectively
column7: Galeazzo Ciano and Saburo Kurusu. The Tripartite Pact was directed primarily at the United States. Its practical effects were limited

column9: and the Japanese declaration of war on the United States propelled
column11: a similar declaration of war from all the other signatories of the Tripartite Pact. ;;;;;;;;;;;;x

project_cybersyn_desc;Project Cybersyn was a Chilean project from 1971 during the presidency of Salvador Allende aimed at constructing a distributed decision support system to aid in the management of the national economy. The project consisted of four modules: an economic simulator
column2: custom software to check factory performance
column3: an operations room
column4: and a national network of telex machines that were linked to one mainframe computer.;;;;;;;x

column1: five_year_plan_desc;The Five-year plan was a list of economic goals
column2: created by Communist Party General Secretary Joseph Stalin
column3: based on his policy of Socialism in One Country. The plan was implemented in 1928 and took effect until 1932. The Soviet Union entered a series of five-year plans which began in 1928 under the rule of Joseph Stalin. Stalin launched what would later be referred to as a "revolution from above" to improve the Soviet Union’s domestic policy. The policies were centered around rapid industrialization and the collectivization of agriculture. Stalin desired to remove and replace any policies created under the New Economic Policy. The plan
column4: overall
column5: was to transition the Soviet Union from a weak
column8: into an industrial powerhouse. While the vision was grand
column9: its planning was ineffective and unrealistic given the short amount of time given to meet the desired goals.;;;;;;;x

column1: accept_armenians_desc;Armenians are a significant minority of Pontus and they have many similarities with our culture
column2: especially in religious tradition. We need to treat them differently from other minorities.;;;;;;;x
also known as the Fund
column3: is an international organization headquartered in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: consisting of 189 countries working to foster global monetary cooperation
column8: promote high employment and sustainable economic growth
column9: and reduce poverty around the world while periodically depending on World Bank for its resources. Formed in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference primarily by the ideas of Harry Dexter White and John Maynard Keynes
column10: it came into formal existence in 1945 with 29 member countries and the goal of reconstructing the international payment system. It now plays a central role in the management of balance of payments difficulties and international financial crises. Countries contribute funds to a pool through a quota system from which countries experiencing balance of payments problems can borrow money.;;;;;;;x

column1: imf_loan_title;Request a Foreign Loan from The International Monetary Fund;;;;;;;x
imf_loan_desc;A member country may request IMF financial assistance if it has an actual or potential balance of payments need—that is
column2: if it lacks or potentially lacks sufficient financing on affordable terms to meet its net international payments (e.g.
column3: imports
column4: external debt redemptions) while maintaining adequate reserve buffers going forward. IMF resources provide a cushion that eases the adjustment policies and reforms that a country must make to correct its balance of payments problem and help restore conditions for strong economic growth.;;;;;;;x

column1: jointheida_desc;The International Development Association (IDA) is an international financial institution which offers concessional loans and grants to the world's poorest developing countries. The IDA is a member of the World Bank Group and is headquartered in Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: United States. It was established in 1960 to complement the existing International Bank for Reconstruction and Development by lending to developing countries which suffer from the lowest gross national income
column4: from troubled creditworthiness
column5: or from the lowest per capita income. Together
column6: the International Development Association and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development are collectively generally known as the World Bank
column7: as they follow the same executive leadership and operate with the same staff.;;;;;;;;x

column1: leavetheida_desc;The International Development Association (IDA) is an international financial institution which offers concessional loans and grants to the world's poorest developing countries. The IDA is a member of the World Bank Group and is headquartered in Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: United States. It was established in 1960 to complement the existing International Bank for Reconstruction and Development by lending to developing countries which suffer from the lowest gross national income
column4: from troubled creditworthiness
column5: or from the lowest per capita income. Together
column6: the International Development Association and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development are collectively generally known as the World Bank
column7: as they follow the same executive leadership and operate with the same staff.;;;;;;;;x

column1: ida_loan_title;Request an International Development Association Loan;;;;;;;;x
ida_loan_desc;The IDA lends to countries with the aim to finance projects that will develop infrastructure and improve education
column2: healthcare
column3: access to clean water and sanitation facilities
column4: and environmental responsibility. It is considered to be the soft lending window of the World Bank
column5: while the IBRD is considered to be the hard lending window. The association offers grants and loans with maturities ranging from 25 to 40 years
column7: and interest rates of 2.8% or 1.25% depending on whether the borrower is a blend country and to which degree it is eligible. Regular IDA-eligible borrowers may take advantage of no-interest loans.;;;;;;;;x

column1: chi_civilized_desc;Westernisation is a process whereby societies come under or adopt Western culture in areas such as industry
column2: technology
column3: politics
column4: economics
column5: lifestyle
column19: and philosophy. During colonialism it often involved spread of Christianity.;;;;;;;;x

column1: create_space_agency_title;Set up a National Space Agency;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

create_space_agency_desc;Setting up a National Space Agency is a necessary requirement for the starting of space programs as it gives the required infrastructure and skills to successfully launch space programs.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column2: a launch vehicle or carrier rocket is a rocket used to carry a payload from Earth's surface into outer space. A launch system includes the launch vehicle
column3: the launch pad
column4: and other infrastructure. Although a carrier rocket's payload is often an artificial satellite placed into orbit
column5: some spaceflights
column8: while others enable spacecraft to escape Earth orbit entirely. Earth orbital launch vehicles typically have at least two stages
column9: and sometimes as many as four or more.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column2: a satellite is an artificial object which has been intentionally placed into orbit. Such objects are sometimes called artificial satellites to distinguish them from natural satellites such as Earth's Moon. Approximately 500 operational satellites are in low-Earth orbit
column3: 50 are in medium-Earth orbit (at 20
column5: and the rest are in geostationary orbit (at 36
column6: 000 km). A few large satellites have been launched in parts and assembled in orbit. Over a dozen space probes have been placed into orbit around other bodies and become artificial satellites to the Moon
column13: and the Sun. Satellites are used for many purposes. Common types include military and civilian Earth observation satellites
column17: and space telescopes. Space stations and human spacecraft in orbit are also satellites. Satellite orbits vary greatly
column18: depending on the purpose of the satellite
column19: and are classified in a number of ways. Well-known (overlapping) classes include low Earth orbit
column21: and geostationary orbit. Satellites are propelled by rockets to their orbits. Usually the launch vehicle itself is a rocket lifting off from a launch pad on land. Some satellites are launched at sea (from a submarine or a mobile maritime platform) or aboard a plane (see air launch to orbit). Satellites are usually semi-independent computer-controlled systems. Satellite subsystems attend many tasks

column1: create_space_man_title;Start a send a man into space program;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
create_space_man_desc;Human spaceflight (also referred to as manned spaceflight) is space travel with a crew or passengers aboard the spacecraft. Spacecraft carrying people may be operated directly
column2: by human crew
column3: or it may be either remotely operated from ground stations on Earth or be autonomous
column4: able to carry out a specific mission with no human involvement.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column2: also known as an orbital station or an orbital space station
column3: is a spacecraft capable of supporting crewmembers
column4: which is designed to remain in space (most commonly as an artificial satellite in low Earth orbit) for an extended period of time and for other spacecraft to dock. A space station is distinguished from other spacecraft used for human spaceflight by lack of major propulsion or landing systems. Instead
column5: other vehicles transport people and cargo to and from the station.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: create_space_probe_title;Set up a space exploration program using space probes;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
create_space_probe_desc;A robotic spacecraft is an uncrewed spacecraft
column2: usually under telerobotic control. A robotic spacecraft designed to make scientific research measurements is often called a space probe. Many space missions are more suited to telerobotic rather than crewed operation
column3: due to lower cost and lower risk factors. In addition
column4: some planetary destinations such as Venus or the vicinity of Jupiter are too hostile for human survival
column5: given current technology. Outer planets such as Saturn
column7: and Neptune are too distant to reach with current crewed spaceflight technology
column8: so telerobotic probes are the only way to explore them.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: create_moon_mission_title;Set up a Manned Mission to the Moon;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

create_moon_mission_desc;A total of twelve men have landed on the Moon. This was accomplished with two US pilot-astronauts flying a Lunar Module on each of six NASA missions across a 41-month period starting on 20 July 1969 UTC
column2: with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on Apollo 11
column3: and ending on 14 December 1972 UTC with Gene Cernan and Jack Schmitt on Apollo 17. Cernan was the last to step off the lunar surface. All Apollo lunar missions had a third crew member who remained on board the Command Module. The last three missions had a rover for increased mobility.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: space_fundings_title;Government Funding of Space Mission Policy;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_fundings_desc;In the early decades of the Space Age
column2: the government space agencies of the Soviet Union and United States pioneered space technology in collaboration with affiliated design bureaus in the USSR and private companies in the US
column3: entirely funding both the development of new spaceflight technologies and the operational costs of spaceflight. The European Space Agency was formed in 1975
column4: largely following the same model of space technology development. Later on
column5: large defense contractors began to develop and operate space launch systems
column6: derived from government rockets. Private spaceflight in Earth orbit includes communications satellites
column9: astronaut transport and sub-orbital and orbital space tourism.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: space_rocket_attempt_public_desc;Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype rocket. We need to launch it to ensure that it works.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_satellite_attempt_public_title;Attempt to send a satellite into space;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_satellite_attempt_public_desc;Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype satellite. We need to launch it to ensure that it works.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_probe_attempt_public_title;Attempt to send a probe into space;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_probe_attempt_public_desc;Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype space exploration probe. We need to launch it to ensure that it works.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_man_attempt_public_title;Attempt to send an Astronaut into space;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

space_man_attempt_public_desc;Our scientists and engineers have trained astronauts to be sent into space. We need to launch a rocket with the astronauts to send our men into space.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
space_station_attempt_public_title;Attempt to establish a Space Station in space;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

space_station_attempt_public_desc;Our scientists and engineers have created a prototype Space Station to be sent into space. We need to launch a rocket with the Space Station to establish in orbit.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
moon_mission_attempt_public_title;Attempt to send a man to the Moon;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

moon_mission_attempt_public_desc;Our Space Agency has formulated and set up a mission that can bring our astronaauts to the moon. All we need to do is to grant them a launch to send the astronauts on their way to the moon.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

referendum_desc;A referendum is a direct vote in which an entire electorate is invited to vote on a particular proposal. This may result in the adoption of a new law or new government type.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: restore_hagia_sophia_desc;Hagia Sophia is the Greek Orthodox Christian patriarchal cathedral. Built in AD 360 at the beginning of the Middle Ages
column2: it was famous in particular for its massive dome. It was the world's largest building and an engineering marvel of its time. It is considered the epitome of Byzantine architecture and is said to have "changed the history of architecture".;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

establish_death_camp_desc;A labour Concentration Camp or work camp is a simplified detention facility where inmates are forced to engage in penal labor as a form of punishment under the criminal code. Labor camps have many common aspects with slavery and with prisons (especially prison farms). Conditions at labor camps vary widely depending on the operators. In the 20th century
column2: a new category of labor camps developed for the imprisonment of virtual millions of people who were not criminals per se
column3: but political opponents (real or imagined) and various so-called undesirables under the totalitarian
column4: both communist and fascist regimes. Some of those camps were dubbed "reeducation facilities" for political coercion
column5: but most others served as backbone of industry and agriculture for the benefit of the state especially in times of war.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: abolish_death_camp_desc;These inhumane methods of killing people have no place in our country.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;
amele_taburlari_desc;Amele Taburlari was a form of unfree labour in the late Ottoman Empire. The term is associated with disarmament and murder of Ottoman Armenian soldiers during World War I
column2: of Ottoman Greeks during the 1913-1919 persecution of Greeks in the Ottoman Empire and also during the Turkish War of Independence.;;;;;;;;x;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column1: claim_pontus_desc;The region of Pontus has been settled by Greeks since antiquity
column2: but the Pontic Greeks have been under Ottoman supression since the 17th Century
column3: it is time to reunite the Pontic Greeks under a single flag.;;;;;;;;;;;;x
